elements.content: Assemblies of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) and Co(NCS)2 afford three supramolecular isomers [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n of square grid networks depending on the assembly conditions. Polymer transformation phenomena are observed among them. Conformation analysis of the ligand is presented to understand the flexibility of the bbtz ligand that influences the assembly topological architectures.
elements.clean_text: Assemblies of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) and Co(NCS)2 afford three supramolecular isomers [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n  of square grid networks depending on the assembly conditions. Polymer transformation phenomena are observed among them. Conformation analysis of the ligand is presented to understand the flexibility of the bbtz ligand that influences the assembly topological architectures.

elements.content: Assemblies of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) and Co(NCS)2 afford three supramolecular isomers, {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3CN)2} n (1), {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3NO2)2} n (2), and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n (3), of square grid networks depending on the assembly conditions. The thermodynamically metastable 1 and 2 transform to thermodynamically stable 3 when 1 and 2 were immersed in refluxing water for 10 days.
elements.clean_text: Assemblies of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) and Co(NCS)2 afford three supramolecular isomers, {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3CN)2} n  (1), {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3NO2)2} n  (2), and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n  (3), of square grid networks depending on the assembly conditions. The thermodynamically metastable 1 and 2 transform to thermodynamically stable 3 when 1 and 2 were immersed in refluxing water for 10 days.

elements.content: The current interest in the crystal engineering of coordination polymer frameworks stems not only from their potential application as functional materials, but also from their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. A variety of appealing interpenetrating structures have been reported recently and reviewed by Batten and Robson. Increasing known examples of coordination polymers based on identical building blocks in the same ratio exhibit different structures. Zaworotko and co-workers have described them as “supramolecular isomers”.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The current interest in the crystal engineering of coordination polymer frameworks stems not only from their potential application as functional materials, but also from their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. A variety of appealing interpenetrating structures have been reported recently and reviewed by Batten and Robson. Increasing known examples of coordination polymers based on identical building blocks in the same ratio exhibit different structures. Zaworotko and co-workers have described them as "supramolecular isomers".

elements.content: Square grid networks are particularly simple and common examples of predictable two-dimensional (2D) metal−organic networks. In some cases, the frameworks generate spacious voids, cavities, and channels, which are usually occupied by solvent molecules. In other cases, interpenetrating structures are formed in which the voids associated with one framework are occupied by one or more independent infinite substructures.
elements.clean_text: Square grid networks are particularly simple and common examples of predictable two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic networks. In some cases, the frameworks generate spacious voids, cavities, and channels, which are usually occupied by solvent molecules. In other cases, interpenetrating structures are formed in which the voids associated with one framework are occupied by one or more independent infinite substructures.

elements.content: Scheme shows three modes of inclined interpenetration observed for square grid networks. Although a large number of square grid networks were reported with different linear spacers, the supramolecular isomers are few. One example is [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n (mpe = 1-methyl-1‘,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane). Solid-to-solid transformation phenomena are observed among the topological isomers [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n . This kind of transformation has been explored little in coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Scheme  shows three modes of inclined interpenetration observed for square grid networks. Although a large number of square grid networks were reported with different linear spacers, the supramolecular isomers are few. One example is [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n  (mpe = 1-methyl-1‘,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane). Solid-to-solid transformation phenomena are observed among the topological isomers [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n . This kind of transformation has been explored little in coordination polymers.

elements.content: Schematic Showing Three Modes of Inclined Interpenetration Observed for Square Grid Networks:  Parallel/Parallel (p−p), Parallel/Diagonal (p−d) and Diagonal/Diagonal (d−d)
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Showing Three Modes of Inclined Interpenetration Observed for Square Grid Networks: Parallel/Parallel (p-p), Parallel/Diagonal (p-d) and Diagonal/Diagonal (d-d)

elements.content: Our synthetic approach starts by focusing on the construction of new topological frameworks using flexible ligands such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane, 1,2-bis(benzotriazol-1-yl)ethane, and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz, Scheme ) due to their variety of conformations. Here we report three supramolecular isomers of a square grid network {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3CN)2} n (1), {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3NO2)2} n (2), and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n (3), generated from the assembly of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) and Co(NCS)2, and polymer transformation phenomena are observed among them.
elements.clean_text: Our synthetic approach starts by focusing on the construction of new topological frameworks using flexible ligands such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane, 1,2-bis(benzotriazol-1-yl)ethane, and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz, Scheme ) due to their variety of conformations. Here we report three supramolecular isomers of a square grid network {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3CN)2} n  (1), {[Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2](CH3NO2)2} n  (2), and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n  (3), generated from the assembly of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) and Co(NCS)2, and polymer transformation phenomena are observed among them.

elements.content: Materials and General Methods. All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. 1,4-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) was synthesized according a literature method. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were obtained for KBr pellets on a Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrophotometer in the 4000−400 cm-1 region. X-ray power diffractions (XRPD) were performed on a D/MAX-3C diffractometer with the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature. Thermogravimetry (TG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was measured on a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA instrument and a SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA−DTA instrument in flowing dinitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and General Methods. All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. 1,4-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) was synthesized according a literature method. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were obtained for KBr pellets on a Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrophotometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. X-ray power diffractions (XRPD) were performed on a D/MAX-3C diffractometer with the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature. Thermogravimetry (TG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was measured on a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA instrument and a SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA-DTA instrument in flowing dinitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

elements.content: Syntheses of {[Co(bbtz) 2 (NCS) 2 ](CH 3 CN) 2 } n (1) and {[Co(bbtz) 2 (NCS) 2 ](CH 3 NO 2 ) 2 } n (2). A methanolic solution (15 mL) of Co(NCS)2 (0.175 g, 1.0 mmol) was layered onto a solution of bbtz (0.240 g, 1.0 mmol) in 15 mL of CH3CN or CH3NO2. The resulting solutions stood for several days to give single crystals of 1 and 2, respectively. The crystals of 1 and 2 lose the included solvent and turn opaque immediately upon removal from the mother liquor, giving [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n (1a) and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] (2a), respectively. Anal. calc. for C26H24CoN14S2 (1a and 2a) (%) C 47.63, H 3.69, N 29.91; found C 47.69, H 3.76, 30.03 for 1a and C 47.46, H 3.74, 29.78 for 2a. IR (KBr/pellet, cm-1):  3133w, 2072vs, 1520s, 1427w, 1350w, 1281m, 1211w, 1130m, 1015m, 988m, 876w, 733m, 675m, and 494w for 1a; 3131w, 2077vs, 2055vs, 1520s, 1430m, 1350w, 1281m, 1211w, 1130m, 1015m, 988m, 876w, 764w, 733m, 675m, 644w, and 486w for 2a.

A methanolic solution (15 mL) of Co(NCS)2 (0.175 g, 1.0 mmol) was layered onto a solution of bbtz (0.240 g, 1.0 mmol) in 15 mL of CH3CN or CH3NO2. The resulting solutions stood for several days to give single crystals of 1 and 2, respectively. The crystals of 1 and 2 lose the included solvent and turn opaque immediately upon removal from the mother liquor, giving [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n  (1a) and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] (2a), respectively. Anal. calc. for C26H24CoN14S2 (1a and 2a) (%) C 47.63, H 3.69, N 29.91; found C 47.69, H 3.76, 30.03 for 1a and C 47.46, H 3.74, 29.78 for 2a. IR (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3133w, 2072vs, 1520s, 1427w, 1350w, 1281m, 1211w, 1130m, 1015m, 988m, 876w, 733m, 675m, and 494w for 1a; 3131w, 2077vs, 2055vs, 1520s, 1430m, 1350w, 1281m, 1211w, 1130m, 1015m, 988m, 876w, 764w, 733m, 675m, 644w, and 486w for 2a.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Co(bbtz) 2 (NCS) 2 ] n (3). A solution of Co(NCS)2 (0.175 g, 1.0 mmol), bbtz (0.240 g, 1.0 mmol), and 20 mL of H2O was heated to 140 °C for 2 days in a Teflon-lined 30 mL bomb and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product 3 was obtained, by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air (yield 76%). Anal. calc. for C26H24CoN14S2 (%) C 47.63, H 3.69, N 29.91; found C 47.53, H 3.72, 29.82. IR (KBr/pellet, cm-1):  3114w, 2083s, 1522m, 1384w, 1343w, 1283m, 1203w, 1129m, 1018m, 988m, 876w, 676m, and 642w.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis  of  [Co(bbtz)  2  (NCS)  2  ]   n    (3). A solution of Co(NCS)2 (0.175 g, 1.0 mmol), bbtz (0.240 g, 1.0 mmol), and 20 mL of H2O was heated to 140 °C for 2 days in a Teflon-lined 30 mL bomb and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product 3 was obtained, by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air (yield 76%). Anal. calc. for C26H24CoN14S2 (%) C 47.63, H 3.69, N 29.91; found C 47.53, H 3.72, 29.82. IR (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3114w, 2083s, 1522m, 1384w, 1343w, 1283m, 1203w, 1129m, 1018m, 988m, 876w, 676m, and 642w.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Suitable single crystals of 1−3 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated MoK α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 193 K. Intensities were collected by the ω scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique (SHELXTL-97). The positions of hydrogen atoms were determined with theoretical calculation. The parameters of the crystal data collection and refinement of 1−3 are given in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table .

The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique (SHELXTL-97). The positions of hydrogen atoms were determined with theoretical calculation. The parameters of the crystal data collection and refinement of 1-3 are given in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table .

Description of Crystal structures {[Co(bbtz) 2 (NCS) 2 ](CH 3 CN) 2 } n (1) and {[Co(bbtz) 2 (NCS) 2 ](CH 3 NO 2 ) 2 } n (2). X-ray crystallographic analyses of 1 and 2 reveal that each of them consists of square grid networks with an identical chemical composition of [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n . The crystal structures of 1 (Figure ) and 2 (Figure ) are almost identical except that 1 encloses CH3CN solvent molecules and 2 embodies CH3NO2 molecules in the voids. The coordination geometry of the Co(II) atom is distorted octahedral, formed equatorially by four nitrogen atoms from four bbtz ligands [Co(1)−N(3) 2.1286(17) Å, Co(1)−N(6) 2.1413(16) Å for 1; Co(1)−N(3) 2.1327(19) Å, Co(1)−N(6) 2.1521(18) Å for 2] and axially by two nitrogen atoms from two thiocyanate anions [Co(1)−N(7) 2.1190(18) Å for 1; Co(1)−N(7) 2.116(2) Å for 2]. The thiocyanate ligand acts as monodentate N-bound ligand and quasi-linear as expected [the N−C−S bond angles are 179.3(2) and 179.4(2)° for 1 and 2, respectively]. The Co−N−C (NCS-) bond angles are 167.99(17) and 166.87(19)° for 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Description of Crystal structures {[Co(bbtz)  2  (NCS)  2  ](CH  3  CN)  2  }   n    (1) and  {[Co(bbtz)  2  (NCS)  2  ](CH  3  NO  2  )  2  }   n    (2). X-ray crystallographic analyses of 1 and 2 reveal that each of them consists of square grid networks with an identical chemical composition of [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n . The crystal structures of 1 (Figure ) and 2 (Figure ) are almost identical except that 1 encloses CH3CN solvent molecules and 2 embodies CH3NO2 molecules in the voids. The coordination geometry of the Co(II) atom is distorted octahedral, formed equatorially by four nitrogen atoms from four bbtz ligands [Co(1)-N(3) 2.1286(17) Å, Co(1)-N(6) 2.1413(16) Å for 1; Co(1)-N(3) 2.1327(19)  Å, Co(1)-N(6) 2.1521(18) Å for 2] and axially by two nitrogen atoms from two thiocyanate anions [Co(1)-N(7) 2.1190(18) Å for 1; Co(1)-N(7) 2.116(2) Å for 2]. The thiocyanate ligand acts as monodentate N-bound ligand and quasi-linear as expected [the N-C-S bond angles are 179.3(2) and 179.4(2)° for 1 and 2, respectively]. The Co-N-C (NCS-) bond angles are 167.99(17) and 166.87(19)° for 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: Square grid network in2.
elements.clean_text: 2  Square grid network in2.

elements.content: Each bbtz acts as a bis-monodentate ligand and connects two cobalt(II) atoms to form the [Co4(bbtz)4] unit containing the 52-membered ring with sides of 13.908 × 15.069 Å in 1 and 14.045 × 15.117 Å in 2, and diagonal distances of 17.887 × 22.827 Å in 1 and 17.592 × 23.284 Å in 2. 1 and 2 are both composed of square grid networks. The layers stack together parallel along the a-axis, and SCN- groups protrude through the cavities of the adjacent layers, and one-dimensional channels along the a-axis are formed which are occupied by the solvent molecules (CH3CN in 1 and CH3NO2 in 2) (Figure for 1 as an example). The interlayer distance is 4.491 Å, and the Co···Co shortest interlayer distance is 8.943 Å equal to a-axis translation in 1. The interlayer distance is 4.424 Å, and the Co···Co shortest interlayer distance is 8.943 Å equal to a-axis translation in 2.
elements.clean_text: Each bbtz acts as a bis-monodentate ligand and connects two cobalt(II) atoms to form the [Co4(bbtz)4] unit containing the 52-membered ring with sides of 13.908 × 15.069 Å in 1 and 14.045 × 15.117 Å in 2, and diagonal distances of 17.887 × 22.827 Å in 1 and 17.592 × 23.284 Å in 2. 1 and 2 are both composed of square grid networks. The layers stack together parallel along the a-axis, and SCN- groups protrude through the cavities of the adjacent layers, and one-dimensional channels along the a-axis are formed which are occupied by the solvent molecules (CH3CN in 1 and CH3NO2 in 2) (Figure  for 1 as an example). The interlayer distance is 4.491 Å, and the Co⋅⋅⋅Co shortest interlayer distance is 8.943 Å equal to a-axis translation in 1. The interlayer distance is 4.424 Å, and the Co⋅⋅⋅Co shortest interlayer distance is 8.943 Å equal to a-axis translation in 2.

elements.content: Description of Crystal Structure [Co(bbtz) 2 (NCS) 2 ] (3). The coordination geometry of the Co(II) atom in 3 is similar to those of 1 and 2, in a distorted octahedral, formed equatorially by four nitrogen atoms from four bbtz ligands [Co(1)−N(3) 2.133(3) Å, Co(1)−N(6)#2 2.159(3) Å] and axially by two nitrogen atoms from two thiocyanate anions [Co(1)−N(7) 2.099(3) Å]. The thiocyanate ligand also acts as a monodentate N-bound ligand and quasi-linear as expected [the N−C−S bond angle is 178.0(4)°]. The Co−N−C (NCS-) bond angle is 166.5(3)°.
elements.clean_text: Description of Crystal Structure [Co(bbtz)  2  (NCS)  2  ] (3). The coordination geometry of the Co(II) atom in 3 is similar to those of 1 and 2, in a distorted octahedral, formed equatorially by four nitrogen atoms from four bbtz ligands [Co(1)-N(3) 2.133(3) Å, Co(1)-N(6)#2 2.159(3) Å] and axially by two nitrogen atoms from two thiocyanate anions [Co(1)-N(7) 2.099(3) Å]. The thiocyanate ligand also acts as a monodentate N-bound ligand and quasi-linear as expected [the N-C-S bond angle is 178.0(4)°]. The Co-N-C (NCS-) bond angle is 166.5(3)°.

elements.content: One would think that the square grid networks constituting 3 are almost equivalent to those found in 1 and 2, but they are different actually. The square grid networks are planar in 1 and 2 but are undulating in 3 with sides of 13.527 × 13.527 Å and diagonal distances of 19.231 × 19.029 Å.
elements.clean_text: One would think that the square grid networks constituting 3 are almost equivalent to those found in 1 and 2, but they are different actually. The square grid networks are planar in 1 and 2 but are undulating in 3 with sides of 13.527 × 13.527 Å and diagonal distances of 19.231 × 19.029 Å.

elements.content: Different from square grid networks in 1 and 2, which stack together parallel, the square grid networks in 3 are interpenetrated. Two sets of parallel layers stack with a separation of 9.217 Å and give a diagonal−diagonal interpenetration (Figure ), and thus, the cavities of each layer are filled by the other layer. Because of the interpenetration, the intersection of the grids gives rise to almost no cavities (Figure ). The crystal of 3 includes no solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text: Different from square grid networks in 1 and 2, which stack together parallel, the square grid networks in 3 are interpenetrated. Two sets of parallel layers stack with a separation of 9.217 Å and give a diagonal-diagonal interpenetration (Figure ), and thus, the cavities of each layer are filled by the other layer. Because of the interpenetration, the intersection of the grids gives rise to almost no cavities (Figure ). The crystal of 3 includes no solvent molecules.

elements.content: Polymer Transformation. The high porosity and relatively low density of the structure found in 1 (1a) (1.338 and 1.189 g/cm3 for 1 and 1a, respectively) and 2 (2a) (1.430 and 1.206 g/cm3 for 2 and 2a, respectively) suggest that their crystals are thermodynamically metastable and their formations could be controlled by the variation of kinetic factors such as diffusion rate and crystallization temperature. It is discovered that 1 and 2 are the sole products when dilute solutions are diffused slowly or highly concentrated solutions are diffused rapidly. The crystals of 1 and 2 lose the included solvent and turn opaque immediately upon removal from the mother liquor, giving [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n (1a) and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] (2a), respectively. The relatively high density (1.476 g/cm3) and low porosity of the structure found in 3 which includes no solvent molecules in the crystals show that the crystals are thermodynamically stable.
elements.clean_text: Polymer Transformation. The high porosity and relatively low density of the structure found in 1 (1a) (1.338 and 1.189 g/cm3 for 1 and 1a, respectively) and 2 (2a) (1.430 and 1.206 g/cm3 for 2 and 2a, respectively) suggest that their crystals are thermodynamically metastable and their formations could be controlled by the variation of kinetic factors such as diffusion rate and crystallization temperature. It is discovered that 1 and 2 are the sole products when dilute solutions are diffused slowly or highly concentrated solutions are diffused rapidly. The crystals of 1 and 2 lose the included solvent and turn opaque immediately upon removal from the mother liquor, giving [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n  (1a) and [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] (2a), respectively. The relatively high density (1.476 g/cm3) and low porosity of the structure found in 3 which includes no solvent molecules in the crystals show that the crystals are thermodynamically stable.

elements.content: Following from this assumption, when 1a and 2a crystals were immersed in refluxing water for 4 h, some of them were converted to 3 and the most of them were found to be converted to 3 after 2 days. And, after the immersion for 10 days, their complete transformation to 3 was revealed by XPRD measurements and the simulation from the X-ray data for a single crystal (Figure ). This phenomenon can be understood on the basis of the supposition that the porous packing polymorph is transformed into the energetically most favorable interpenetration structure. This result is completely in contrast to that of [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n catenane isomers. For [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n catenane isomers, when immersed in refluxing water, the perpendicular interpenetration structure is transformed to the packing polymorph, showing the energetically most favorable packing structure.
elements.clean_text: Following from this assumption, when 1a and 2a crystals were immersed in refluxing water for 4 h, some of them were converted to 3 and the most of them were found to be converted to 3 after 2 days. And, after the immersion for 10 days, their complete transformation to 3 was revealed by XPRD measurements and the simulation from the X-ray data for a single crystal (Figure ). This phenomenon can be understood on the basis of the supposition that the porous packing polymorph is transformed into the energetically most favorable interpenetration structure. This result is completely in contrast to that of [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n  catenane isomers. For [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2] n  catenane isomers, when immersed in refluxing water, the perpendicular interpenetration structure is transformed to the packing polymorph, showing the energetically most favorable packing structure.

elements.content: XPRD results:  (a) measured for3; (b) measured for 1a; (c) measured for 2a; (d) measured after immersing 1a in refluxing water for 4 h; (e) measured after immersing 2a in refluxing water for 4 h; (f) measured after immersing 1a in refluxing water for 2 days; (g) measured after immersing 2a in refluxing water for 2 days; (h) measured after immersing 1a in refluxing water for 10 days, indicating the transformation to 3; (i) measured after immersing 2a in refluxing water for 10 days, indicating the transformation to 3; (j) simulated for 3.
elements.clean_text: 7  XPRD results: (a) measured for3; (b) measured for 1a; (c) measured for 2a; (d) measured after immersing 1a in refluxing water for 4 h; (e) measured after immersing 2a in refluxing water for 4 h; (f) measured after immersing 1a in refluxing water for 2 days; (g) measured after immersing 2a in refluxing water for 2 days; (h) measured after immersing 1a in refluxing water for 10 days, indicating the transformation to 3; (i) measured after immersing 2a in refluxing water for 10 days, indicating the transformation to 3; (j) simulated for 3.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis. The thermal behaviors of 1a, 2a, and 3 were measured with a TG-DSC method under a nitrogen stream. The measurements show that 1a, 2a, and 3 have very similar thermal properties. 1a, 2a, and 3 were stable up to 275, 276, and 262 °C, respectively. Above these temperatures the organic liagnds bbtz were lost, and the complexes were decomposed. The main weight losses happened in the ranges of 270−370 °C. The residues at 500 °C for 1a, 2a, and 3 are 30.2, 30.6, and 28.6%, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric Analysis. The thermal behaviors of 1a, 2a, and 3 were measured with a TG-DSC method under a nitrogen stream. The measurements show that 1a, 2a, and 3 have very similar thermal properties. 1a, 2a, and 3 were stable up to 275, 276, and 262 °C, respectively. Above these temperatures the organic liagnds bbtz were lost, and the complexes were decomposed. The main weight losses happened in the ranges of 270-370 °C. The residues at 500 °C for 1a, 2a, and 3 are 30.2, 30.6, and 28.6%, respectively.

elements.content: Conformation Analysis. To understand the flexibility of the bbtz ligand that influences the assembly topological architectures in 1, 2, and 3. The conformation analysis of the ligand is presented. 3 contains one independent bbtz which acts as a shorter spacer, with the shortest N···N distances of 10.483 Å between the two donor atoms. Each bbtz in 3 exhibits the gauche−gauche conformation (Scheme ). While 1 and 2 both contain two independent bbtz ligands and all bbtz ligands adopt the trans-gauche conformation and act as middle or longer spacers, with the shortest N···N distances of 10.521 and 11.068 Å in 1 and 10.623 and 11.037 Å in 2 between the two donor atoms. The N···N distances between two donor atoms of the gauche−gauche conformation bbtz molecules are about 0.04−0.59 Å shorter than the corresponding N···N distances of the trans-gauche conformation bbtz. The dihedral angles between the two triazole ring planes is 124.0°, and the dihedral angles between the triazole ring planes and phenyl ring plane in one bbtz are 72.6 and 73.0° in 3. The dihedral angles between the two triazole ring planes are 0° in two different spacers, and the dihedral angles between the triazole ring plane and the phenyl ring plane are 88.6 and 81.1° in the middle spacer and longer spacer, respectively, in 1. The dihedral angles between the two triazole ring planes are also 0° in two different spacers, and the dihedral angles between the triazole ring plane and the phenyl ring plane are 88.9 and 83.1° in the middle spacer and longer spacer, respectively, in 2. The two triazole ring planes are almost perpendicular to the phenyl ring plane in one bbtz in 1 and 2. All these data indicate the change of the spacer conformations and the relative orientations of the triazole rings are responsible for the N···N and Co···Co distances. The diversity in ligand conformation leads to a variation in structural motifs. The conformational flexibility of the spacers observed in three polymers are responsible for the various relative orientations by the donor group and the donor nitrogen atoms, which results in the difference in the metal−metal distances and the topology of the networks.
elements.clean_text: Conformation Analysis. To understand the flexibility of the bbtz ligand that influences the assembly topological architectures in 1, 2, and 3. The conformation analysis of the ligand is presented. 3 contains one independent bbtz which acts as a shorter spacer, with the shortest N⋅⋅⋅N distances of 10.483 Å between the two donor atoms. Each bbtz in 3 exhibits the gauche-gauche conformation (Scheme ). While 1 and 2 both contain two independent bbtz ligands and all bbtz ligands adopt the trans-gauche conformation and act as middle or longer spacers, with the shortest N⋅⋅⋅N distances of 10.521 and 11.068 Å in 1 and 10.623 and 11.037 Å in 2 between the two donor atoms. The N⋅⋅⋅N distances between two donor atoms of the gauche-gauche conformation bbtz molecules are about 0.04-0.59 Å shorter than the corresponding N⋅⋅⋅N distances of the trans-gauche conformation bbtz. The dihedral angles between the two triazole ring planes is 124.0°, and the dihedral angles between the triazole ring planes and phenyl ring plane in one bbtz are 72.6 and 73.0° in 3. The dihedral angles between the two triazole ring planes are 0° in two different spacers, and the dihedral angles between the triazole ring plane and the phenyl ring plane are 88.6 and 81.1° in the middle spacer and longer spacer, respectively, in 1. The dihedral angles between the two triazole ring planes are also 0° in two different spacers, and the dihedral angles between the triazole ring plane and the phenyl ring plane are 88.9 and 83.1° in the middle spacer and longer spacer, respectively, in 2. The two triazole ring planes are almost perpendicular to the phenyl ring plane in one bbtz in 1 and 2. All these data indicate the change of the spacer conformations and the relative orientations of the triazole rings are responsible for the N⋅⋅⋅N and Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances. The diversity in ligand conformation leads to a variation in structural motifs. The conformational flexibility of the spacers observed in three polymers are responsible for the various relative orientations by the donor group and the donor nitrogen atoms, which results in the difference in the metal-metal distances and the topology of the networks.

elements.content: Three supramolecular isomers [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n of square grid networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The structures of cobalt(II) polymers are profoundly influenced by the reaction conditions (the solution diffuse reaction at room temperature affords 1 in CH3OH/CH3CN medium and 2 in CH3OH/CH3NO2 medium, and the hydrothermal reaction at 140 °C produces 3). Polymer transformation phenomena are observed among them. The thermodynamically metastable 1(1a) and 2(2a) transform to thermodynamically stable 3 when 1a and 2a were immersed in refluxing water for 10 days. The diversity in ligand conformation leads to a variation in structural motifs. The conformation analysis of the ligand is presented to understand the flexibility of bbtz ligand that influences the assembly topological architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion and Comments

Three supramolecular isomers [Co(bbtz)2(NCS)2] n  of square grid networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The structures of cobalt(II) polymers are profoundly influenced by the reaction conditions (the solution diffuse reaction at room temperature affords 1 in CH3OH/CH3CN medium and 2 in CH3OH/CH3NO2 medium, and the hydrothermal reaction at 140 °C produces 3). Polymer transformation phenomena are observed among them. The thermodynamically metastable 1(1a) and 2(2a) transform to thermodynamically stable 3 when 1a and 2a were immersed in refluxing water for 10 days. The diversity in ligand conformation leads to a variation in structural motifs. The conformation analysis of the ligand is presented to understand the flexibility of bbtz ligand that influences the assembly topological architectures.

elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content: Synthesis of [Co(bbtz) 2 (NCS) 2 ] n (3). A solution of Co(NCS)2 (0.175 g, 1.0 mmol), bbtz (0.240 g, 1.0 mmol), and 20 mL of H2O was heated to 140 °C for 2 days in a Teflon-lined 30 mL bomb and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product 3 was obtained, by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air (yield 76%). Anal. calc. for C26H24CoN14S2 (%) C 47.63, H 3.69, N 29.91; found C 47.53, H 3.72, 29.82. IR (KBr/pellet, cm-1):  3114w, 2083s, 1522m, 1384w, 1343w, 1283m, 1203w, 1129m, 1018m, 988m, 876w, 676m, and 642w.
cln_elements.clean_text: Synthesis  of  [Co(bbtz)  2  (NCS)  2  ]   n    (3). A solution of Co(NCS)2 (0.175 g, 1.0 mmol), bbtz (0.240 g, 1.0 mmol), and 20 mL of H2O was heated to 140 °C for 2 days in a Teflon-lined 30 mL bomb and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product 3 was obtained, by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air (yield 76%). Anal. calc. for C26H24CoN14S2 (%) C 47.63, H 3.69, N 29.91; found C 47.53, H 3.72, 29.82. IR (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3114w, 2083s, 1522m, 1384w, 1343w, 1283m, 1203w, 1129m, 1018m, 988m, 876w, 676m, and 642w.

metadata.title:
Three Supramolecular Isomers of Square Grid Networks from the
Assembly of a Flexible Spacer and Co(NCS)2:  Structures and
Polymer Transformation
